channel.title: Comments on: SQL Advent 2011 Day 14: EXCEPT and INTERSECT SET Operations
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: Bruno, you are right..the copy and paste gremlins switched the values on me..i have fixed it..thanks
item.content:encoded: Bruno, you are right..the copy and paste gremlins switched the values on me..i have fixed it..thanks

item.title: By: bruno
item.dc:creator: bruno
item.description: Shouldn't last two examples switch places? The first one should use EXCEPT instead INTERSECT and the last should use INTERSECT?
item.content:encoded: Shouldn’t last two examples switch places? The first one should use EXCEPT instead INTERSECT and the last should use INTERSECT?

item.title: By: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.dc:creator: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.content:encoded:
Tracy,

Quite an interesting approach to the common problem of many parameters.

I have to admit, I don’t use these operators often except for solving problems on forums. I will keep them in mind for my future queries we use in production.

item.title: By: Tracy McKibben (RealSQLGuy)
item.dc:creator: Tracy McKibben (RealSQLGuy)
item.content:encoded:
Two of favorite new language features in 2008. I’ve been pushing them heavily onto our developers, but as you’ve observed, they keep doing things the old way.

I’ve also used these operators in performance tuning:
http://www.real-sql-guy.com/2011/11/stop-performance-problem-with-intersect.html
